subject: Keri, Adobe wants to hear from you!
body:
Chance to win $500 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
Dear Keri
We would love to hear from customers like yourself about the creative and digital activities you do, so that we can make improvements to our products and services to ensure they’re truly suited to your needs.
As a thank you, we’re entering survey participants into a drawing for a chance to win one of the following prizes:
One $500 USD Amazon.com gift card
One $250 USD Amazon.com gift card
Five $100 USD Amazon.com gift cards
Fifty $25 USD Amazon.com gift cards
If you’re interested in sharing your thoughts with us and being entered into the drawing, please click the link below. The survey will take around 15 minutes to complete.
Start survey
(If you want to complete this survey in multiple sessions, no problem! Your progress will be saved).
Thank you in advance. We greatly appreciate your time and input!
Adobe Customer Research

Hi Keri,
We are preparing a deck for an onsite event.  Can you check out the generation slides (notes are in it).  I am looking for a very different look/feel.  The remaining deck can be incorporated into the new look.  Here is the path of the generation slides.  
 
The working deck for the session is 
25 LeadersSummit DRAFT v2draft
 
deck to give you an idea of all the pieces.  I just need it all different since the client has seen this last year.
 
At this point, I am just looking for the Generations slides to be reformatted.  I would like to share with the client on Monday.  Does that give you enough time?  Let me know, I can be flexible.
 
Thank you.

OpenAI just turned on image generation in ChatGPT, powered by GPT-4o — and it’s now available to 
everyone
, from paying subscribers (Plus, Pro, Team) to folks on the Free tier.
So… how is that useful?
Well, I used it to generate two ads for a fictional company — in just a few minutes. No designer, no photographer, no creative team. Just me and ChatGPT.
Here’s how it went:
I opened ChatGPT, selected GPT-4o, and typed the prompt: “Give me an ad concept for a new healthy drink that gives you probiotics and has no sugar.” Here’s what it gave me:
Introducing: 
Purebiotics
 — The refreshing drink that boosts your gut health without a single grain of sugar.
🥤 Probiotics-powered – Supports digestion, immunity, and overall wellness
🚫 0 Sugar, 0 Guilt – Sweetened naturally, no artificial stuff ever
🌱 Clean Ingredients – Plant-based, non-GMO, and crafted with care
💧 Light. Crisp. Alive. – A sparkling sip that makes wellness taste amazing
Fuel your body. Feed your gut.
Drink Purebiotics. Feel the difference.
I liked the concept, so next I asked ChatGPT to turn it into an Instagram ad. 
I refined the prompt about four times, zeroing in on the details — until I got something I liked: a woman walking out of the gym, drinking Purebiotics. That’s the image on the left (above).
Then I pushed it a bit further. I wrote: “Now make a similar one with two friends talking — one Asian — and walking down a street in Manhattan after the gym. One of them is drinking this drink.”
Boom — it gave me the second image (on the right).
All this took about five minutes.
Hey, I know. Are these the best ads ever? No. But they’re pretty good for zero budget and no human involvement apart from mine.
I didn’t have to hire a copy editor, a photographer, three models, make a prototype bottle, or set up lighting. You name it — I pretty much didn’t have to do it.
I just opened ChatGPT after walking the dog and made two ads while drinking my morning coffee.
This is not a gimmick — it’s a signal.
A big part of how marketing teams operate is about to change. Content creation, especially at scale, is becoming faster, cheaper, and way more accessible with AI.
If you’re in marketing, comms, or creative strategy, 
learn how to prompt
. 
"Prompting" refers to the art of writing clear instructions for AI systems - essentially telling the AI exactly what you want it to create.
AI won’t replace your talent — it will multiply it. And yes, a real marketer will absolutely get better results than I did. But that’s the point: with the right skills, this tech becomes a serious competitive advantage. 
  
Before You Buy Your House, Look 30 Years Ahead with AlphaGeo
Climate change is quietly redrawing the map of where it’s safe — and smart — to live and invest.
From wildfires to rising insurance costs, the impact is no longer hypothetical. 
The New York Times
 recently shared a guide for homebuyers to avoid high-risk areas. But for most people, navigating that kind of complexity is daunting.
That’s why I’m excited about what my husband Parag is building at AlphaGeo.
Let’s say you’re considering buying a home, opening an office, or investing in land. AlphaGeo helps you look beyond today and understand what that location might look like 10, 20, or 50 years from now. 
😎 
It shows you:
The climate risks that could affect the area — like floods, droughts, or hurricanes
How resilient the location is, based on local infrastructure, adaptation efforts, and planning
What your future insurance, utilities, or maintenance costs might look like
And how all of this could shape the property’s long-term value
AlphaGeo has built a dataset of 60 billion datapoints covering every coordinate on the globe and providing 20 actionable indicators that measure any location's climate risk, adaptation capacity to offset those risks, and predictions of insurance premiums and other expenses. It then uses AI in predicting valuations.
Why it matters: 
Climate change is expected to destroy $1.5 trillion in US home value over the next 30 years. This loss will be uneven — driven by specific risks like flooding, wildfire, and extreme heat in certain locations. Investing smartly by identifying which places are vulnerable and which are adapting, is going to be essential for protecting long-term value.
Click here
 to see if your home is in the safe zone (use your work email) or learn more: 
www.alphageo.ai
  
WOMAN IN TECH
Meet Dr. Iman Abuzeid, CEO of Incredible Health
Celebrating this week's Woman in Tech 
🥳
: 
Meet Dr. Iman Abuzeid, CEO and co-founder of Incredible Health
, and only the fourth Black woman to lead a billion-dollar company. 
Born in Saudi Arabia to Sudanese parents, Dr. Abuzeid grew up surrounded by medicine—her father and brothers are all surgeons. She earned her medical degree from University College London, then moved to the US and completed her MBA at The Wharton School.
While working in consulting and health tech, Dr. Abuzeid saw a disconnect: hospitals struggling to find nurses, and nurses struggling to find good jobs. In 2017, she co-founded Incredible Health to fix both sides of the problem:
Unlike traditional job boards, Incredible Health flips the hiring process: 
healthcare employers apply to nurses
, not the other way around.
The platform uses AI to match nurses with roles that fit their experience, preferences, and location.
This reduces hiring time from the national average of 90 days to 
just 20
, helping hospitals fill critical roles faster and giving nurses better opportunities.
Today, Incredible Health is used by over 1,500 hospitals and 1 million nurses across the US. The platform reached a $1.65 billion valuation in 2022, and saves hospitals an average of $2 million per year.
Dr. Abuzeid’s work for nurses and hospitals has earned her recognition in TIME’s Next 2024 list, as well as Forbes’ America’s Richest Self Made Women list in 2023. 
🤗 
  
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️

 and

here

Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hi everyone,
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
Is Talking to ChatGPT Making You Lonely?
Disney’s New Robot Looks Like It’s Alive
Your Photos Could Save Japan’s Cherry Blossoms
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
Is Talking to ChatGPT Making You Lonely?
OpenAI has released its 
first ever research into how using ChatGPT affects people’s emotional wellbeing. 
The studies were conducted in partnership with the MIT Media Lab and included two parts: an analysis of 40 million real-world ChatGPT interactions, and a four-week experiment with nearly 1,000 participants using the chatbot daily.
Here’s what they found:
Only a small number of users engage emotionally with ChatGPT, while most use it for practical tasks like writing or coding.
Those who did use it like a companion often spent 30 minutes or more with it daily.
The more the participants trusted and “bonded” with ChatGPT, the more likely they were to report feelings of loneliness and a growing reliance on the chatbot.
Those who interacted with a voice mode of a different gender than their own reported greater emotional dependency and increased loneliness.
Women appeared to be more affected overall
 — after 4 weeks of regular ChatGPT use, they showed a greater decline in social interaction compared to men.
These early findings don’t claim definitive answers. As AI professor Kate Devlin pointed out, self-reported data can miss the nuance of how people truly feel.
Still, it’s a meaningful first step in measuring what effect AI companions have on our social lives.
  
Disney’s New Robot Looks Like It’s Alive
These two small robots became unexpected stars at Nvidia’s GTC 2025 conference.
Inspired by Star Wars, 
“Besh and Grek” are real-life droids built by Disney Imagineering
. They can walk, turn, and respond with a level of coordination and timing that’s noticeably smooth. Their subtle, lifelike movements and pauses made them stand out to many in the audience.
The droids were developed using Newton, Nvidia’s new physics engine developed in collaboration with Google DeepMind and Disney Research. 
What makes Newton different? At the center of the physics engine is something called a 
digital twin 
— a virtual version of the robot that can be trained 
entirely in simulation
. Before the physical droid ever takes a step, its digital twin practices walking, reacting, and interacting in a virtual environment that mirrors real-world physics.
Here’s how it works:
The digital twin attempts tasks like walking across a floor or reacting to someone nearby.
Newton calculates what would happen in the real world, down to how the robot’s weight shifts or how fast it turns.
Over time, the robot learns what works and what doesn’t — and 
only once it’s reliable enough in simulation does it move to the real world
.
To make the Disney droids feel more human, the creative team at Disney first sketched out how emotions like shyness or curiosity should look on the robots, down to specific gestures and facial cues. Then, using Newton, the virtual models were trained to perform those expressions physically, with lifelike movement and timing.
Nvidia sees potential far beyond entertainment for Newton; the company estimates the market for simulation-trained robots could reach 
$10 trillion
. This would include applications in healthcare, logistics, and manufacturing — any setting where reliability matters and physical trial-and-error is too risky or expensive. 
It would be exciting to see these robots act in films as well. Their lifelike movements could bring characters to life without relying so much on CGI.
  
Your Photos Could Save Japan’s Cherry Blossoms
Each spring, millions gather under Japan’s cherry blossoms—snapping photos and sipping drinks. The tradition, 
known as hanami
, is all about slowing down and enjoying the blossoms with friends, food, and good weather.
But behind the scenes, many of these iconic trees are quietly aging out. Most were planted after WWII, and now, decades later, local governments are struggling to keep them healthy with limited budgets and staff.
To support these trees, Japanese beverage company Kirin Brewery 
has launched Sakura AI Camera, a free tool that lets anyone take a photo of a cherry tree and get an instant health check
. The AI looks at trunk size and shape to estimate age and vitality, then shares the data with local officials so they know which trees need care.
The company hopes to turn casual springtime moments into acts of conservation, helping more people take part in preserving cherry blossoms and keeping the tradition alive for generations to come. 
🌸 
What do you think of this approach?
Would you take photos to help save cherry blossom trees?
Absolutely! Happy to trade one snap for a thousand blossoms. 📸 
Maybe, if I'm already taking pictures anyway. 🤔 
No thanks, I don't want my stroll to turn into a science project! 🌸

Cohort 5 of my Generative AI for Business Executives course is now live. 
Step into the future of business — 
Enroll now
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
FuriosaAI, a Korean startup making AI chips, 
has turned down an $800 million offer from Meta
. 🤯 Instead of being acquired, the company wants to grow on its own and eventually go public. 
The company’s latest chip, called RNGD, is designed for AI inferencing—the process of running trained AI models to generate results. It’s Furiosa’s answer to Nvidia’s chips, which dominate this space today. 
RNGD is already being tested by companies like LG and Saudi Aramco. It’s built using advanced manufacturing from TSMC, the world’s largest chipmaker, and high-speed memory from SK Hynix—both crucial for delivering the performance needed to compete with industry giants. 
Meta, which is investing heavily in its own AI infrastructure, saw Furiosa as a potential strategic fit. But with growing customer interest and a funding round that’s already ahead of target, Furiosa believes it’s better positioned to grow on its own. 
  
Ps. I just started watching Adolescence on Netflix. 
It’s intense and uncomfortable at times, but it offers a very unfiltered look into what shapes boys today: loneliness, peer pressure, online influences, and learning to be masculine. 
If you're raising or mentoring teenage boys, this show opens the door to real, necessary conversations about what they’re feeling, who they’re listening to, and the kind of men they’re becoming. 
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️

From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <
r.parrilla@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, March 20, 2025 1:27 PM
To:
 Keri Luo <
k.luo@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Another fillable pdf for Boston Scientific? 
😊
 
Hi Keri, how are you?
We need to create a fillable pdf for Boston Scientific’s “Leading Inclusively in APAC” (similar to 
the one you created for Canada
). Much of the content is the same, and you can copy from the document you’ve already created. 
 
I gathered the main takeaways from 
this workshop
 and wrote them out below. Do you think it’s possible to have a draft by Friday or Monda
y?
 
Please note that I’ve made some tweaks in the language from the Canada version – some parts are not exactly the same. 
 
Thank you so very much!
 
 
 
Diversity:
 The 
composition
 of our team. The different life experiences that exist in our team.
Inclusion:
 What we 
proactively do
 to engage the diversity in our team. Making our team feel understood, respected, and part of the team. 
 
 
Key Reflection Questions for Driving Inclusion on Your Team
BUILD
Consider the diverse talent at your location…
·
        
Who has been
 well-represented
?
·
        
Whose voice has been noticeably 
under-represented, or even 
un
represented
?
BELONG
·
        
What 
actions
 have you taken personally as a leader 
to foster a sense of belonging
 on your team?
·
        
How have you engaged your team
 and leveraged their unique talents?
ADVANCE
What have you done to make sure your historically excluded talent have 
access to the opportunities, relationships and networks
 they need to succeed and advance?
 
Valuing Diversity in Asia Pacific
Racial and ethnic minorities:
 There are hundreds of ethnic groups across Asia Pacific. Southeast Asia alone represents 100+ ethnic groups and a population of 655 million people who speak more than 1,000 different languages and dialects. Proactively make sure that the way we recruit, hire, and develop our talent is equitable and bias-free. 
Women
: According to Equileap’s Gender Equality in Asia Pacific report, women make up only 17% of boards of directors, 4% of CEOS, and 26% of senior managers. How can we make sure we evaluate women’s performance fairly? 
Colorism (light skin preference)
 is the practice of favouring lighter skin over darker skin, particularly within the same ethnic group. People with fairer skin are seen as more beautiful and tend to receive better treatment by society and institutions. How can we avoid unconsciously giving people with lighter skin fewer development opportunities? 
Class/socioeconomic status
: Are we unconsciously giving people from wealthier socioeconomic backgrounds more attention, more credibility, more development opportunities, more airtime? What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
Caste: 
Caste systems categorize people into hierarchical social groups and are based on a person’s job/occupation and descent. While no longer legal, people’s perceived caste still often influences how they are treated. What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
 
To lead inclusively at Boston Scientific, I will:
Expand my circle of “go-to” people. 
Create opportunities for less talkative/extroverted people to demonstrate their capabilities.
Check against affinity bias or confirmation bias when I say a team member is not the “right fit.”    
Identify high performers based on objective, consistent criteria. 
Mentor or sponsor talent of varying backgrounds (not just those who are similar to me).
Be intentional about ensuring the people in my networks are culturally- and gender-diverse. 
Give my discretionary time to a variety of people at BSC, not just those who are high performers or with whom I feel comfortable. 
 
Up groups or “in groups” in organizations…
Tend to have access to power, control, and information 
Tend to unconsciously rely on stereotypes 
Tend to not think too much about their membership in an “in group”
What are some “in groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Down groups or “out groups” in organizations…
Have less power, control, and information
Tend to experience extra scrutiny, stereotypes, and confirmation bias
Are susceptible to 
stereotype threat
, where anxiety about confirming negative stereotypes can precipitate self-doubt, and sometimes ends up hindering their ability to perform confidently and at their maximum level.
Tend to be very aware of being in an “out group”
What are some “out groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Remember… “in groups” can be “out groups” in different contexts. 
 
It’s our job as people leaders to create a culture where all team members feel like they’re part of your “in group” - heard, respected, understood, and like their contributions matter. Only then can exceptional performance be expected!
 
Coded language: 
Words or phrases that may appear neutral or harmless on the surface but carry underlying biases which can influence perceptions and opportunities in the workplace.
  
Examples:
“He lacks executive presence” or “lacks polish”
“She’s not a cultural fit here”
(To a Black colleague): “Wow, you’re so articulate”
“You have an aggressive communication style”
“Her hair style could have been more professional”
“Zara was a diversity hire”
 
Concrete actions you can take to lead inclusively
Build Awareness, Listen Actively, Inclusive Environment
Empower Team, Value Contributions, Encourage Diverse Perspectives
Provide Quality Feedback, Equity in Evaluations, Self-Awareness
•
         
Have inclusive conversations by asking open-ended questions and listening deeply
•
         
Learn about unconscious biases and their impact on decision-making.
•
         
Build cultural literacy on unfamiliar cultures; understand different work, communication, and conflict resolution styles.
•
         
Give full attention and understanding before responding.
•
         
Ask clarifying questions and confirm understanding.
•
         
Create a culture where team members feel safe expressing diverse opinions without fear of embarrassment.
•
         
Rotate the order of speakers in meetings to make sure everyone has a chance to contribute.
 
•
        
Make sure everyone has the resources needed for success.
•
        
Create conditions for team members to take risks and make their own decisions.
•
        
Proactively engage team members rather than waiting for them to speak up.
•
        
Thank and recognise team members in ways that are meaningful to them.
•
        
Publicly highlight accomplishments, especially for those who are less vocal.
•
        
Actively seek out diverse viewpoints when making decisions or solving problems.
•
        
Encourage ideas that challenge the status quo and demonstrate appreciation for novel suggestions.
 
•
        
Offer specific, actionable feedback that focuses on behaviour, not personal judgment.
•
        
Make sure feedback is delivered in culturally competent ways.
•
        
Build trust by following through on feedback and advice received from others.
•
        
Review hiring practices and ensure job descriptions are inclusive.
•
        
Regularly review performance criteria to ensure they are fair and equitable for all backgrounds.
•
        
Resist judgment, recognizing that you may not fully see others' challenges.
 
 
Sample questions for inclusive conversations: 
What is a “perfect” day for you in your job? How often do any of those circumstances occur?
How well do you feel you’re recognised for your accomplishments and contributions to the team?
What gets in the way of you being successful in your job? How might that be prevented and how can I help you with that?
What negative experiences might you have here that I am unaware of, and how can I help you?
What challenges your sense of belonging or feelings of fitting in and being part of the team?
What was the best part of your week (work or non-work related)?
What recent project or achievement are you most proud of, and why?
Who or what had the biggest impact on who you are today?
What’s something important to you that you’d like your colleagues to know about? 
What’s a common way in which you’re often misunderstood?
 
Your commitments to action
What is 1 action you can take to…
Recognise and raise up your team members
 including those who have been historically excluded (e.g., Ensure specific behavioural performance evaluation criteria are set and agreed upon in advance and are applied consistently.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Build your understanding of the varying experiences
 of talent at your location (e.g., During one-on-ones, ask “What’s a ‘perfect’ day for you at work, and what might make those circumstances happen more frequently?”)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Drive discussions about inclusion
 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Develop your intercultural competence 
(e.g., Seek to understand why some team members may not feel like they can be their authentic selves at work.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

access to the opportunities, relationships and networks
 they need to succeed and advance?
 
Valuing Diversity in Asia Pacific
Racial and ethnic minorities:
 There are hundreds of ethnic groups across Asia Pacific. Southeast Asia alone represents 100+ ethnic groups and a population of 655 million people who speak more than 1,000 different languages and dialects. Proactively make sure that the way we recruit, hire, and develop our talent is equitable and bias-free. 
Women
: According to Equileap’s Gender Equality in Asia Pacific report, women make up only 17% of boards of directors, 4% of CEOS, and 26% of senior managers. How can we make sure we evaluate women’s performance fairly? 
Colorism (light skin preference)
 is the practice of favouring lighter skin over darker skin, particularly within the same ethnic group. People with fairer skin are seen as more beautiful and tend to receive better treatment by society and institutions. How can we avoid unconsciously giving people with lighter skin fewer development opportunities? 
Class/socioeconomic status
: Are we unconsciously giving people from wealthier socioeconomic backgrounds more attention, more credibility, more development opportunities, more airtime? What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
Caste: 
Caste systems categorize people into hierarchical social groups and are based on a person’s job/occupation and descent. While no longer legal, people’s perceived caste still often influences how they are treated. What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
 
To lead inclusively at Boston Scientific, I will:
Expand my circle of “go-to” people. 
Create opportunities for less talkative/extroverted people to demonstrate their capabilities.
Check against affinity bias or confirmation bias when I say a team member is not the “right fit.”    
Identify high performers based on objective, consistent criteria. 
Mentor or sponsor talent of varying backgrounds (not just those who are similar to me).
Be intentional about ensuring the people in my networks are culturally- and gender-diverse. 
Give my discretionary time to a variety of people at BSC, not just those who are high performers or with whom I feel comfortable. 
 
Up groups or “in groups” in organizations…
Tend to have access to power, control, and information 
Tend to unconsciously rely on stereotypes 
Tend to not think too much about their membership in an “in group”
What are some “in groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Down groups or “out groups” in organizations…
Have less power, control, and information
Tend to experience extra scrutiny, stereotypes, and confirmation bias
Are susceptible to 
stereotype threat
, where anxiety about confirming negative stereotypes can precipitate self-doubt, and sometimes ends up hindering their ability to perform confidently and at their maximum level.
Tend to be very aware of being in an “out group”
What are some “out groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Remember… “in groups” can be “out groups” in different contexts. 
 
It’s our job as people leaders to create a culture where all team members feel like they’re part of your “in group” - heard, respected, understood, and like their contributions matter. Only then can exceptional performance be expected!
 
Coded language: 
Words or phrases that may appear neutral or harmless on the surface but carry underlying biases which can influence perceptions and opportunities in the workplace.
  
Examples:
“He lacks executive presence” or “lacks polish”
“She’s not a cultural fit here”
(To a Black colleague): “Wow, you’re so articulate”
“You have an aggressive communication style”
“Her hair style could have been more professional”
“Zara was a diversity hire”
 
Concrete actions you can take to lead inclusively
Build Awareness, Listen Actively, Inclusive Environment
Empower Team, Value Contributions, Encourage Diverse Perspectives
Provide Quality Feedback, Equity in Evaluations, Self-Awareness
•
       
Have inclusive conversations by asking open-ended questions and listening deeply
•
       
Learn about unconscious biases and their impact on decision-making.
•
       
Build cultural literacy on unfamiliar cultures; understand different work, communication, and conflict resolution styles.
•
       
Give full attention and understanding before responding.
•
       
Ask clarifying questions and confirm understanding.
•
       
Create a culture where team members feel safe expressing diverse opinions without fear of embarrassment.
•
       
Rotate the order of speakers in meetings to make sure everyone has a chance to contribute.
 
•
       
Make sure everyone has the resources needed for success.
•
       
Create conditions for team members to take risks and make their own decisions.
•
       
Proactively engage team members rather than waiting for them to speak up.
•
       
Thank and recognise team members in ways that are meaningful to them.
•
       
Publicly highlight accomplishments, especially for those who are less vocal.
•
       
Actively seek out diverse viewpoints when making decisions or solving problems.
•
       
Encourage ideas that challenge the status quo and demonstrate appreciation for novel suggestions.
 
•
       
Offer specific, actionable feedback that focuses on behaviour, not personal judgment.
•
       
Make sure feedback is delivered in culturally competent ways.
•
       
Build trust by following through on feedback and advice received from others.
•
       
Review hiring practices and ensure job descriptions are inclusive.
•
       
Regularly review performance criteria to ensure they are fair and equitable for all backgrounds.
•
       
Resist judgment, recognizing that you may not fully see others' challenges.
 
 
Sample questions for inclusive conversations: 
What is a “perfect” day for you in your job? How often do any of those circumstances occur?
How well do you feel you’re recognised for your accomplishments and contributions to the team?
What gets in the way of you being successful in your job? How might that be prevented and how can I help you with that?
What negative experiences might you have here that I am unaware of, and how can I help you?
What challenges your sense of belonging or feelings of fitting in and being part of the team?
What was the best part of your week (work or non-work related)?
What recent project or achievement are you most proud of, and why?
Who or what had the biggest impact on who you are today?
What’s something important to you that you’d like your colleagues to know about? 
What’s a common way in which you’re often misunderstood?
 
Your commitments to action
What is 1 action you can take to…
Recognise and raise up your team members
 including those who have been historically excluded (e.g., Ensure specific behavioural performance evaluation criteria are set and agreed upon in advance and are applied consistently.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Build your understanding of the varying experiences
 of talent at your location (e.g., During one-on-ones, ask “What’s a ‘perfect’ day for you at work, and what might make those circumstances happen more frequently?”)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Drive discussions about inclusion
 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Develop your intercultural competence 
(e.g., Seek to understand why some team members may not feel like they can be their authentic selves at work.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her)

I gathered the main takeaways from 
this workshop
 and wrote them out below. Do you think it’s possible to have a draft by Friday or Monda
y?
 
Please note that I’ve made some tweaks in the language from the Canada version – some parts are not exactly the same. 
 
Thank you so very much!
 
 
 
Diversity:
 The 
composition
 of our team. The different life experiences that exist in our team.
Inclusion:
 What we 
proactively do
 to engage the diversity in our team. Making our team feel understood, respected, and part of the team. 
 
 
Key Reflection Questions for Driving Inclusion on Your Team
BUILD
Consider the diverse talent at your location…
·
        
Who has been
 well-represented
?
·
        
Whose voice has been noticeably 
under-represented, or even 
un
represented
?
BELONG
·
        
What 
actions
 have you taken personally as a leader 
to foster a sense of belonging
 on your team?
·
        
How have you engaged your team
 and leveraged their unique talents?
ADVANCE
What have you done to make sure your historically excluded talent have 
access to the opportunities, relationships and networks
 they need to succeed and advance?
 
Valuing Diversity in Asia Pacific
Racial and ethnic minorities:
 There are hundreds of ethnic groups across Asia Pacific. Southeast Asia alone represents 100+ ethnic groups and a population of 655 million people who speak more than 1,000 different languages and dialects. Proactively make sure that the way we recruit, hire, and develop our talent is equitable and bias-free. 
Women
: According to Equileap’s Gender Equality in Asia Pacific report, women make up only 17% of boards of directors, 4% of CEOS, and 26% of senior managers. How can we make sure we evaluate women’s performance fairly? 
Colorism (light skin preference)
 is the practice of favouring lighter skin over darker skin, particularly within the same ethnic group. People with fairer skin are seen as more beautiful and tend to receive better treatment by society and institutions. How can we avoid unconsciously giving people with lighter skin fewer development opportunities? 
Class/socioeconomic status
: Are we unconsciously giving people from wealthier socioeconomic backgrounds more attention, more credibility, more development opportunities, more airtime? What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
Caste: 
Caste systems categorize people into hierarchical social groups and are based on a person’s job/occupation and descent. While no longer legal, people’s perceived caste still often influences how they are treated. What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
 
To lead inclusively at Boston Scientific, I will:
Expand my circle of “go-to” people. 
Create opportunities for less talkative/extroverted people to demonstrate their capabilities.
Check against affinity bias or confirmation bias when I say a team member is not the “right fit.”    
Identify high performers based on objective, consistent criteria. 
Mentor or sponsor talent of varying backgrounds (not just those who are similar to me).
Be intentional about ensuring the people in my networks are culturally- and gender-diverse. 
Give my discretionary time to a variety of people at BSC, not just those who are high performers or with whom I feel comfortable. 
 
Up groups or “in groups” in organizations…
Tend to have access to power, control, and information 
Tend to unconsciously rely on stereotypes 
Tend to not think too much about their membership in an “in group”
What are some “in groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Down groups or “out groups” in organizations…
Have less power, control, and information
Tend to experience extra scrutiny, stereotypes, and confirmation bias
Are susceptible to 
stereotype threat
, where anxiety about confirming negative stereotypes can precipitate self-doubt, and sometimes ends up hindering their ability to perform confidently and at their maximum level.
Tend to be very aware of being in an “out group”
What are some “out groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Remember… “in groups” can be “out groups” in different contexts. 
 
It’s our job as people leaders to create a culture where all team members feel like they’re part of your “in group” - heard, respected, understood, and like their contributions matter. Only then can exceptional performance be expected!
 
Coded language: 
Words or phrases that may appear neutral or harmless on the surface but carry underlying biases which can influence perceptions and opportunities in the workplace.
  
Examples:
“He lacks executive presence” or “lacks polish”
“She’s not a cultural fit here”
(To a Black colleague): “Wow, you’re so articulate”
“You have an aggressive communication style”
“Her hair style could have been more professional”
“Zara was a diversity hire”
 
Concrete actions you can take to lead inclusively
Build Awareness, Listen Actively, Inclusive Environment
Empower Team, Value Contributions, Encourage Diverse Perspectives
Provide Quality Feedback, Equity in Evaluations, Self-Awareness
•
         
Have inclusive conversations by asking open-ended questions and listening deeply
•
         
Learn about unconscious biases and their impact on decision-making.
•
         
Build cultural literacy on unfamiliar cultures; understand different work, communication, and conflict resolution styles.
•
         
Give full attention and understanding before responding.
•
         
Ask clarifying questions and confirm understanding.
•
         
Create a culture where team members feel safe expressing diverse opinions without fear of embarrassment.
•
         
Rotate the order of speakers in meetings to make sure everyone has a chance to contribute.
 
•
        
Make sure everyone has the resources needed for success.
•
        
Create conditions for team members to take risks and make their own decisions.
•
        
Proactively engage team members rather than waiting for them to speak up.
•
        
Thank and recognise team members in ways that are meaningful to them.
•
        
Publicly highlight accomplishments, especially for those who are less vocal.
•
        
Actively seek out diverse viewpoints when making decisions or solving problems.
•
        
Encourage ideas that challenge the status quo and demonstrate appreciation for novel suggestions.
 
•
        
Offer specific, actionable feedback that focuses on behaviour, not personal judgment.
•
        
Make sure feedback is delivered in culturally competent ways.
•
        
Build trust by following through on feedback and advice received from others.
•
        
Review hiring practices and ensure job descriptions are inclusive.
•
        
Regularly review performance criteria to ensure they are fair and equitable for all backgrounds.
•
        
Resist judgment, recognizing that you may not fully see others' challenges.
 
 
Sample questions for inclusive conversations: 
What is a “perfect” day for you in your job? How often do any of those circumstances occur?
How well do you feel you’re recognised for your accomplishments and contributions to the team?
What gets in the way of you being successful in your job? How might that be prevented and how can I help you with that?
What negative experiences might you have here that I am unaware of, and how can I help you?
What challenges your sense of belonging or feelings of fitting in and being part of the team?
What was the best part of your week (work or non-work related)?
What recent project or achievement are you most proud of, and why?
Who or what had the biggest impact on who you are today?
What’s something important to you that you’d like your colleagues to know about? 
What’s a common way in which you’re often misunderstood?
 
Your commitments to action
What is 1 action you can take to…
Recognise and raise up your team members
 including those who have been historically excluded (e.g., Ensure specific behavioural performance evaluation criteria are set and agreed upon in advance and are applied consistently.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Build your understanding of the varying experiences
 of talent at your location (e.g., During one-on-ones, ask “What’s a ‘perfect’ day for you at work, and what might make those circumstances happen more frequently?”)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Drive discussions about inclusion
 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Develop your intercultural competence 
(e.g., Seek to understand why some team members may not feel like they can be their authentic selves at work.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter

 to engage the diversity in our team. Making our team feel understood, respected, and part of the team. 
 
 
Key Reflection Questions for Driving Inclusion on Your Team
BUILD
Consider the diverse talent at your location…
·
        
Who has been
 well-represented
?
·
        
Whose voice has been noticeably 
under-represented, or even 
un
represented
?
BELONG
·
        
What 
actions
 have you taken personally as a leader 
to foster a sense of belonging
 on your team?
·
        
How have you engaged your team
 and leveraged their unique talents?
ADVANCE
What have you done to make sure your historically excluded talent have 
access to the opportunities, relationships and networks
 they need to succeed and advance?
 
Valuing Diversity in Asia Pacific
Racial and ethnic minorities:
 There are hundreds of ethnic groups across Asia Pacific. Southeast Asia alone represents 100+ ethnic groups and a population of 655 million people who speak more than 1,000 different languages and dialects. Proactively make sure that the way we recruit, hire, and develop our talent is equitable and bias-free. 
Women
: According to Equileap’s Gender Equality in Asia Pacific report, women make up only 17% of boards of directors, 4% of CEOS, and 26% of senior managers. How can we make sure we evaluate women’s performance fairly? 
Colorism (light skin preference)
 is the practice of favouring lighter skin over darker skin, particularly within the same ethnic group. People with fairer skin are seen as more beautiful and tend to receive better treatment by society and institutions. How can we avoid unconsciously giving people with lighter skin fewer development opportunities? 
Class/socioeconomic status
: Are we unconsciously giving people from wealthier socioeconomic backgrounds more attention, more credibility, more development opportunities, more airtime? What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
Caste: 
Caste systems categorize people into hierarchical social groups and are based on a person’s job/occupation and descent. While no longer legal, people’s perceived caste still often influences how they are treated. What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
 
To lead inclusively at Boston Scientific, I will:
Expand my circle of “go-to” people. 
Create opportunities for less talkative/extroverted people to demonstrate their capabilities.
Check against affinity bias or confirmation bias when I say a team member is not the “right fit.”    
Identify high performers based on objective, consistent criteria. 
Mentor or sponsor talent of varying backgrounds (not just those who are similar to me).
Be intentional about ensuring the people in my networks are culturally- and gender-diverse. 
Give my discretionary time to a variety of people at BSC, not just those who are high performers or with whom I feel comfortable. 
 
Up groups or “in groups” in organizations…
Tend to have access to power, control, and information 
Tend to unconsciously rely on stereotypes 
Tend to not think too much about their membership in an “in group”
What are some “in groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Down groups or “out groups” in organizations…
Have less power, control, and information
Tend to experience extra scrutiny, stereotypes, and confirmation bias
Are susceptible to 
stereotype threat
, where anxiety about confirming negative stereotypes can precipitate self-doubt, and sometimes ends up hindering their ability to perform confidently and at their maximum level.
Tend to be very aware of being in an “out group”
What are some “out groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Remember… “in groups” can be “out groups” in different contexts. 
 
It’s our job as people leaders to create a culture where all team members feel like they’re part of your “in group” - heard, respected, understood, and like their contributions matter. Only then can exceptional performance be expected!
 
Coded language: 
Words or phrases that may appear neutral or harmless on the surface but carry underlying biases which can influence perceptions and opportunities in the workplace.
  
Examples:
“He lacks executive presence” or “lacks polish”
“She’s not a cultural fit here”
(To a Black colleague): “Wow, you’re so articulate”
“You have an aggressive communication style”
“Her hair style could have been more professional”
“Zara was a diversity hire”
 
Concrete actions you can take to lead inclusively
Build Awareness, Listen Actively, Inclusive Environment
Empower Team, Value Contributions, Encourage Diverse Perspectives
Provide Quality Feedback, Equity in Evaluations, Self-Awareness
•
         
Have inclusive conversations by asking open-ended questions and listening deeply
•
         
Learn about unconscious biases and their impact on decision-making.
•
         
Build cultural literacy on unfamiliar cultures; understand different work, communication, and conflict resolution styles.
•
         
Give full attention and understanding before responding.
•
         
Ask clarifying questions and confirm understanding.
•
         
Create a culture where team members feel safe expressing diverse opinions without fear of embarrassment.
•
         
Rotate the order of speakers in meetings to make sure everyone has a chance to contribute.
 
•
        
Make sure everyone has the resources needed for success.
•
        
Create conditions for team members to take risks and make their own decisions.
•
        
Proactively engage team members rather than waiting for them to speak up.
•
        
Thank and recognise team members in ways that are meaningful to them.
•
        
Publicly highlight accomplishments, especially for those who are less vocal.
•
        
Actively seek out diverse viewpoints when making decisions or solving problems.
•
        
Encourage ideas that challenge the status quo and demonstrate appreciation for novel suggestions.
 
•
        
Offer specific, actionable feedback that focuses on behaviour, not personal judgment.
•
        
Make sure feedback is delivered in culturally competent ways.
•
        
Build trust by following through on feedback and advice received from others.
•
        
Review hiring practices and ensure job descriptions are inclusive.
•
        
Regularly review performance criteria to ensure they are fair and equitable for all backgrounds.
•
        
Resist judgment, recognizing that you may not fully see others' challenges.
 
 
Sample questions for inclusive conversations: 
What is a “perfect” day for you in your job? How often do any of those circumstances occur?
How well do you feel you’re recognised for your accomplishments and contributions to the team?
What gets in the way of you being successful in your job? How might that be prevented and how can I help you with that?
What negative experiences might you have here that I am unaware of, and how can I help you?
What challenges your sense of belonging or feelings of fitting in and being part of the team?
What was the best part of your week (work or non-work related)?
What recent project or achievement are you most proud of, and why?
Who or what had the biggest impact on who you are today?
What’s something important to you that you’d like your colleagues to know about? 
What’s a common way in which you’re often misunderstood?
 
Your commitments to action
What is 1 action you can take to…
Recognise and raise up your team members
 including those who have been historically excluded (e.g., Ensure specific behavioural performance evaluation criteria are set and agreed upon in advance and are applied consistently.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Build your understanding of the varying experiences
 of talent at your location (e.g., During one-on-ones, ask “What’s a ‘perfect’ day for you at work, and what might make those circumstances happen more frequently?”)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Drive discussions about inclusion
 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Develop your intercultural competence 
(e.g., Seek to understand why some team members may not feel like they can be their authentic selves at work.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)
(she/her) 
Why pronouns matter
Head of Client Solutions
LCW

Try Replay

Sign in
 for free with your existing Dropbox account.

From the Workspace, click “Add files” and choose where to import your media from. 
That’s it!
Learn how
Review together in real time
Bring your team together with live review. Watch, mark up, and comment on the same video, image, or audio file in Replay—like you’re all in the same room, no matter where collaborators are located.

 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)

subject: RE: Another fillable pdf for Boston Scientific? 😊
body:
Hi Rebecca! 
I’m doing well. Thanks!
 
Yes, I will have it ready for you by the end of tomorrow.
 
 
~Keri
 
 
From:
 Rebecca Parrilla <r.parrilla@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Thursday, March 20, 2025 1:27 PM
To:
 Keri Luo <k.luo@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Another fillable pdf for Boston Scientific? 
😊
 
Hi Keri, how are you?
We need to create a fillable pdf for Boston Scientific’s “Leading Inclusively in APAC” (similar to 
the one you created for Canada
). Much of the content is the same, and you can copy from the document you’ve already created. 
 
I gathered the main takeaways from 
this workshop
 and wrote them out below. Do you think it’s possible to have a draft by Friday or Monda
y?
 
Please note that I’ve made some tweaks in the language from the Canada version – some parts are not exactly the same. 
 
Thank you so very much!
 
 
 
Diversity:
 The 
composition
 of our team. The different life experiences that exist in our team.
Inclusion:
 What we 
proactively do
 to engage the diversity in our team. Making our team feel understood, respected, and part of the team. 
 
 
Key Reflection Questions for Driving Inclusion on Your Team
BUILD
Consider the diverse talent at your location…
·
        
Who has been
 well-represented
?
·
        
Whose voice has been noticeably 
under-represented, or even 
un
represented
?
BELONG
·
        
What 
actions
 have you taken personally as a leader 
to foster a sense of belonging
 on your team?
·
        
How have you engaged your team
 and leveraged their unique talents?
ADVANCE
What have you done to make sure your historically excluded talent have 
access to the opportunities, relationships and networks
 they need to succeed and advance?
 
Valuing Diversity in Asia Pacific
Racial and ethnic minorities:
 There are hundreds of ethnic groups across Asia Pacific. Southeast Asia alone represents 100+ ethnic groups and a population of 655 million people who speak more than 1,000 different languages and dialects. Proactively make sure that the way we recruit, hire, and develop our talent is equitable and bias-free. 
Women
: According to Equileap’s Gender Equality in Asia Pacific report, women make up only 17% of boards of directors, 4% of CEOS, and 26% of senior managers. How can we make sure we evaluate women’s performance fairly? 
Colorism (light skin preference)
 is the practice of favouring lighter skin over darker skin, particularly within the same ethnic group. People with fairer skin are seen as more beautiful and tend to receive better treatment by society and institutions. How can we avoid unconsciously giving people with lighter skin fewer development opportunities? 
Class/socioeconomic status
: Are we unconsciously giving people from wealthier socioeconomic backgrounds more attention, more credibility, more development opportunities, more airtime? What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
Caste: 
Caste systems categorize people into hierarchical social groups and are based on a person’s job/occupation and descent. While no longer legal, people’s perceived caste still often influences how they are treated. What could we do to proactively keep this in mind the next time we’re making a people decision?
 
To lead inclusively at Boston Scientific, I will:
Expand my circle of “go-to” people. 
Create opportunities for less talkative/extroverted people to demonstrate their capabilities.
Check against affinity bias or confirmation bias when I say a team member is not the “right fit.”    
Identify high performers based on objective, consistent criteria. 
Mentor or sponsor talent of varying backgrounds (not just those who are similar to me).
Be intentional about ensuring the people in my networks are culturally- and gender-diverse. 
Give my discretionary time to a variety of people at BSC, not just those who are high performers or with whom I feel comfortable. 
 
Up groups or “in groups” in organizations…
Tend to have access to power, control, and information 
Tend to unconsciously rely on stereotypes 
Tend to not think too much about their membership in an “in group”
What are some “in groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Down groups or “out groups” in organizations…
Have less power, control, and information
Tend to experience extra scrutiny, stereotypes, and confirmation bias
Are susceptible to 
stereotype threat
, where anxiety about confirming negative stereotypes can precipitate self-doubt, and sometimes ends up hindering their ability to perform confidently and at their maximum level.
Tend to be very aware of being in an “out group”
What are some “out groups” within Boston Scientific?
 
Remember… “in groups” can be “out groups” in different contexts. 
 
It’s our job as people leaders to create a culture where all team members feel like they’re part of your “in group” - heard, respected, understood, and like their contributions matter. Only then can exceptional performance be expected!
 
Coded language: 
Words or phrases that may appear neutral or harmless on the surface but carry underlying biases which can influence perceptions and opportunities in the workplace.
  
Examples:
“He lacks executive presence” or “lacks polish”
“She’s not a cultural fit here”
(To a Black colleague): “Wow, you’re so articulate”
“You have an aggressive communication style”
“Her hair style could have been more professional”
“Zara was a diversity hire”
 
Concrete actions you can take to lead inclusively
Build Awareness, Listen Actively, Inclusive Environment
Empower Team, Value Contributions, Encourage Diverse Perspectives
Provide Quality Feedback, Equity in Evaluations, Self-Awareness
•
         
Have inclusive conversations by asking open-ended questions and listening deeply
•
         
Learn about unconscious biases and their impact on decision-making.
•
         
Build cultural literacy on unfamiliar cultures; understand different work, communication, and conflict resolution styles.
•
         
Give full attention and understanding before responding.
•
         
Ask clarifying questions and confirm understanding.
•
         
Create a culture where team members feel safe expressing diverse opinions without fear of embarrassment.
•
         
Rotate the order of speakers in meetings to make sure everyone has a chance to contribute.
 
•
        
Make sure everyone has the resources needed for success.
•
        
Create conditions for team members to take risks and make their own decisions.
•
        
Proactively engage team members rather than waiting for them to speak up.
•
        
Thank and recognise team members in ways that are meaningful to them.
•
        
Publicly highlight accomplishments, especially for those who are less vocal.
•
        
Actively seek out diverse viewpoints when making decisions or solving problems.
•
        
Encourage ideas that challenge the status quo and demonstrate appreciation for novel suggestions.
 
•
        
Offer specific, actionable feedback that focuses on behaviour, not personal judgment.
•
        
Make sure feedback is delivered in culturally competent ways.
•
        
Build trust by following through on feedback and advice received from others.
•
        
Review hiring practices and ensure job descriptions are inclusive.
•
        
Regularly review performance criteria to ensure they are fair and equitable for all backgrounds.
•
        
Resist judgment, recognizing that you may not fully see others' challenges.
 
 
Sample questions for inclusive conversations: 
What is a “perfect” day for you in your job? How often do any of those circumstances occur?
How well do you feel you’re recognised for your accomplishments and contributions to the team?
What gets in the way of you being successful in your job? How might that be prevented and how can I help you with that?
What negative experiences might you have here that I am unaware of, and how can I help you?
What challenges your sense of belonging or feelings of fitting in and being part of the team?
What was the best part of your week (work or non-work related)?
What recent project or achievement are you most proud of, and why?
Who or what had the biggest impact on who you are today?
What’s something important to you that you’d like your colleagues to know about? 
What’s a common way in which you’re often misunderstood?
 
Your commitments to action
What is 1 action you can take to…
Recognise and raise up your team members
 including those who have been historically excluded (e.g., Ensure specific behavioural performance evaluation criteria are set and agreed upon in advance and are applied consistently.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Build your understanding of the varying experiences
 of talent at your location (e.g., During one-on-ones, ask “What’s a ‘perfect’ day for you at work, and what might make those circumstances happen more frequently?”)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Drive discussions about inclusion
 with your direct reports and teams (e.g., Introduce inclusive language to your team and explain the reasons behind it.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
Develop your intercultural competence 
(e.g., Seek to understand why some team members may not feel like they can be their authentic selves at work.)
(Space for writing on a fillable pdf here)
 
 
 
 
Rebecca M. Parrilla
 
(MBA, Latina, LGBTQ, Mom)

subject: China’s Dark Factories Are Running Themselves 24/7
body:
PLUS: Up for some "vibe coding"?  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 20, 2025   |   
Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hi Everyone, 
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
China’s Dark Factories Are Running Themselves 24/7
AI Titans Unite: UAE-Backed Project Attracts Tech Giants
Who’s Up For Some “Vibe Coding”?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
China’s Dark Factories Are Running Themselves 24/7
Factories with no workers. Machines running 24/7 in absolute darkness. Robots handling everything from assembly to quality control. No humans so no lights needed. It sounds like science fiction, but in China, it’s becoming reality.
China is leading the shift toward dark factories
—these manufacturing plants that operate with little to no human involvement.
The highly automated facilities use AI, robotics, and 5G to keep production running around the clock, boosting efficiency and cutting costs. The trend is growing fast in China, the global “manufacturing superpower” which accounts for over 30% of global production.
Some of the biggest names in Chinese manufacturing are already running dark factories, including Midea Group – the home appliance giant that produces 
30% of the world’s air conditioners
 with almost no human involvement. 
Another example is Changying Precision Technology Company, a factory in Dongguan, China, which 
replaced 90% of its human workforce with robots
, reducing the number of employees from 650 to 60 and in the process. The company experienced a 250% increase in production by using automated production lines with robotic arms, automated machining equipment, autonomous transport trucks, and other automated systems in the warehouse. 
While dark factories eliminate traditional factory jobs, a new kind of worker is emerging—one that sits between office jobs and manual labor.
Instead of line workers assembling products by hand, 
factories now need technicians who keep robots running
, workers who manage AI-driven supply chains, and specialists who fix smart machines before they break down. 
These aren’t the traditional “blue-collar” factory jobs of the past, but they aren’t strictly “white-collar” either—
some call them “gray-collar“ professions.
  
AI Titans Unite: UAE-Backed Project Attracts Tech Giants
Dubai Skyline
I
n a significant move, 
Nvidia and Elon Musk’s xAI have joined a consortium backed by 
Abu Dhabi’s MGX
—a state-supported technology investment firm focused on AI and advanced technologies
—alongside Microsoft and BlackRock, the world’s largest asset manager.
The $100 Billion Vision
The AI Infrastructure Partnership aims to mobilize up to $100 billion, including debt financing, to expand AI infrastructure, primarily in the US and OECD countries. This includes:
Building state-of-the-art data centers
Developing energy facilities to power AI applications
Supporting cutting-edge AI technologies
Energy Considerations
The partnership recognizes the massive energy demands of AI infrastructure and plans to address them sustainably. 
By 2034, data center energy consumption is projected to hit 1,580 terawatt-hours—
matching India’s current annual usage.
 
😲
 
To tackle this, NextEra Energy and GE Vernova are collaborating on diverse, scalable energy solutions for AI data centers.
Global Competition
This follows US President Donald Trump’s January 2025 announcement of Stargate, a $500 billion private-sector AI infrastructure push backed by SoftBank Group, OpenAI, and Oracle. 
This alliance, now strengthened by Nvidia and xAI, highlights the escalating global race for AI supremacy. 
And the United Arab Emirates (UAE)’s influence is undeniable—MGX’s backing, potentially linked to sovereign wealth giants like Mubadala, anchors the partnership firmly in the Middle East.
  
Who’s Up For Some “Vibe Coding”?
What's your plan this weekend? How about doing some "vibe coding"?
It's the latest trend buzzing in Silicon Valley
, and here’s what it’s all about:
The term "vibe coding" was coined by Andrej Karpathy, renowned computer scientist and OpenAI co-founder. 
Last month, he described this new approach where developers "fully give in to the vibes" and "forget the code even exists." 
Instead of manually typing, 
they rely on AI-assisted coding 
through natural language prompts, letting AI generate the code for them.
Karpathy sometimes doesn’t even type the English prompts —he uses SuperWhisper to dictate commands to the Cursor coding assistant.
The result? Code gets written. Apps get built. And instead of spending hours debugging or waiting for your tech engineers, you get to be creative and prototype ideas. According to Y Combinator, most startups coming through their incubator are now generating 90% of their code with AI tools like ChatGPT.
Still, some might say that it’s better to write your own code than spend hours debugging what AI gives them. What do you think?
Would you let AI code for you?
Yes! AI writes the code and I get the credit—why not? 😎 
Maybe… but if the code crashes, I’m blaming the vibes. 🤨 
No way! We're real devs, we debug our own disasters. 🔥 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
Spotify is expanding its AI-narrated audiobook collection through 
a new partnership with ElevenLabs
, allowing authors to create audiobooks in 29 languages and upload them through Spotify’s distribution service, Findaway Voices. AI-generated titles are labeled after a review process. 
This makes audiobook production far cheaper. ElevenLabs offers a free tier for short recordings, while its $99/month Pro plan generates up to 500 minutes of narration—
far less than the thousands of dollars a human narrator typically charges
. 
For professional voice actors, this shift means finding new ways to stay relevant. Some are already exploring licensing deals, where their voices are used to train AI models, allowing them to earn royalties rather than being replaced outright. Others may specialize in high-end projects where a human touch is still in demand. 
  
Who's up for some vibe coding this weekend? 
I haven’t coded seriously in a while, but I’m diving back in—no technical skills needed, just a chatbot and some creativity. 
If you'd like me to share my experience and how to get started, drop me a comment. 
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️ 
ps. Let's be friends on 
LinkedIn
 and 
Instagram
, if you like this newsletter, share it with your friends and family 
here
. 
  
FROM OUR PARTNERS

 is transforming the way working professionals consume business news.

subject: Gen Z Is Skipping the 9-to-5 and Cashing In
body:
PLUS: Who’s the better manager, Moms or MBAs?  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
March 18, 2025   |   
Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hi Everyone, 
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
Gen Z Is Skipping the 9-to-5 and Cashing In
Insilico Medicine Secures $110M to Speed Up AI Drug Discovery
Who’s The Better Manager: Moms or MBAs?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
Gen Z Is Skipping the 9-to-5 and Cashing In
For most kids, a side hustle means mowing lawns for pocket money. For Chase Gallagher (pictured above), it meant building a $1.5 million landscaping business… before he could even drive.
There is a growing wave of Gen Z entrepreneurs — born between 1997 and 2012 — who aren’t waiting for a diploma to start making money. 
Take Cal AI, for example, which I just downloaded a few days ago to track my calories. Snap a picture of your meal, and the app instantly estimates calories and macros. 
It’s pulled in 5M+ downloads and $2M in revenue last month, but here’s the thing: it wasn’t built by a big tech firm. It was created by two 18-year-olds. 
😎 
A Fortune article by Orianna Rosa Royle highlights 
how Gen Z is skipping the traditional career path
, turning side gigs into six-figure businesses while their peers are still in school.
Here’s the story:
Gen Z isn’t buying into the corporate dream. 
They’ve seen their parents struggle with layoffs, burnout, and jobs that barely keep up with the cost of living. Stability in a traditional 9-to-5 is no longer a guarantee, so they’re looking for another way.
Tech has made entrepreneurship more accessible than ever. 
With nothing more than a phone and an internet connection, young people are launching Etsy shops, reselling sneakers, trading stocks, or building entire brands on TikTok. Now with AI writing the code for them too, the barriers to entry are even lower, and the potential for success is massive.
The numbers back it up. 
On LinkedIn, “founder” is the second-fastest-growing job title among Gen Z. Nearly 2 out of 3 say they already have a side gig or plan to start one soon.
Why it matters
: Big companies can’t afford to ignore this shift. Gen Z isn’t waiting around for their next promotion—with more and more Gen Zs turning “founders,“ traditional employers risk losing an entire generation to independent ventures and freelancing.
To attract young talent in the modern age, businesses need to rethink what they offer. Competitive salaries aren’t enough; Gen Z values 
flexibility, autonomy, and purpose-driven work
. 
I often hear people say Gen Z is lazy and doesn’t want to work, but I don’t see it that way. They’re willing to work hard, as long as they’re given the flexibility to do it on their own terms. 
🤗 
  
Insilico Medicine Secures $110M to Speed Up AI Drug Discovery
Insilico CSO Feng Ren (L) and founder Alex Zhavoronkov (R). Image: Insilico Medicine
Biotech company Insilico Medicine is using AI to rethink drug discovery. Now, 
with a fresh $110 million in funding pushing its valuation past $1 billion
, the startup is considering a Hong Kong IPO.
Developing a new drug is notoriously slow and expensive—it can take over a decade and billions of dollars before a single treatment reaches patients. Insilico wants to change that with AI, making the process faster, cheaper, and more precise. 
At the core of Insilico’s approach is Pharma.AI
, which analyzes vast biological datasets and predict which molecules are most likely to work, reducing the need for excessive trial and error. 
Insilico is already delivering results
—its leading drug candidate, Rentosertib, for a serious lung disease, reached early clinical trials in just 2.5 years, a process that normally takes up to six.
The company is making big deals
 by licensing its AI-generated drugs to pharmaceutical giants like Sanofi and Fosun Pharma, securing $3.5 billion in contract value.
The startup’s pipeline now includes 30 drug candidates, with 10 receiving clearance from the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to proceed with human trials.
Beyond discovery, 
Insilico is using AI to speed up lab work
. The company is testing humanoid robots in its China lab to automate repetitive tasks, collect data, and reduce human error, all in an attempt to speed up research.
If Insilico succeeds, it could reshape the entire drug discovery process. By combining AI, real drug candidates, and even lab robots, the company is tackling the whole process, not just one piece of it. Faster, cheaper, and maybe even better—this could be a glimpse of how future drugs come to life.
  
Who’s The Better Manager: Moms or MBAs?
Think about the best manager you've ever had. Were they great because of what they learned in business school—or because they understood people, priorities, and how to keep everything running smoothly under pressure?
According to Indian billionaire and founder Manoj Bhargava, 
the toughest management challenges don’t come with just a corporate title
. They happen in everyday life, where the stakes are much more real and daunting.
In line with that logic, Bhargava believes that the best place to learn management isn’t a classroom… it’s your mom.
Bhargava explained that moms juggle budgets, resolve conflicts, and manage “employees” they can’t fire (aka their kids). While MBAs focus on strategy and theory, moms make tough decisions in real time, with real consequences. 
It’s a compelling argument. But does experience alone build great leaders, or do MBAs still offer something essential? What do you think?
Who's the better manager: Moms or MBAs?
Moms! 👩🏼‍🦰They’ve been running a high-stakes startup since day one. 
Why not both! 😎 A CEO mindset with a mom’s efficiency is unstoppable. 
MBAs! 👩🏼‍🎓Boardrooms and bedtime battles aren’t the same. 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
Lex Fridman, known for his highly popular long-form podcast featuring guests like Elon Musk and Noam Chomsky, recently interviewed Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. Fridman’s discussions attract a wide audience, and 
Modi’s episode has already reached 2M views in two days
. 
Modi spoke on AI saying that while AI is powerful, he firmly believed that "no technology can ever replace the boundless creativity and imagination of the human mind”. He also emphasized that India’s AI talent will remain crucial to the world as it modernizes in this new era. 
  
Honored to be 
featured by ELLE Magazine
 as a leading woman on International Women’s Day. 
Here’s to all the women who inspire, lead, and pave the way for the next generation. 
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️ 
ps. Let's be friends on 
LinkedIn
 and 
Instagram
, if you like this newsletter, share it with your friends and family 
here
. 
  
FROM OUR PARTNERS
Run ads IRL with AdQuick
With 
AdQuick
, you can now easily plan, deploy and measure campaigns just as easily as digital ads, making them a no-brainer to add to your team’s toolbox.
You can learn more at 
www.AdQuick.com

Could be improved 😕

Hi Nicole,

subject: RE: Link to BSC's "Valuing Diversity" eLearning from last year (global examples)

subject: Re: 1 pager example
body:
Thanks so much. You are fast!! 🙂
I like them both but prefer they layout of PDF #3.
And I agree - adding the photo was a good call.
Can this be saved somewhere in Dropbox in the non-PDF version (Word or PPT) & PDF version? Not sure where it should go.
Thank you again for getting this back so fast!

Sent:
 Monday, March 17, 2025 4:23 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: 1 pager example
 
 
Hi Nicole,
I’ve attached two more design ideas for you to choose from. Please note that the design in the first PDF is based on our page template. 
For PDF #2, I utilized the same template but removed the slide samples. It’s a bit dull without images, so I included a photo. 
In PDF #3, I created another page layout using more elements from the website design.
 
Please let me know if any adjustments are needed. 
 
 
 
Thanks,
~Keri
