subject: Build A Million Dollar Business With An AI Team
body:
PLUS: Would you let a sweaty robot do your chores?  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
February 27, 2025   |   
Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
Hi Everyone, 
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
Build A Million Dollar Business With An AI Team
Could Cyborg Cockroaches Have Helped During the LA Fires?
Would You Get This Robot Do Your Chores?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
Build A Million Dollar Business With An AI Team
Picture this: A million-dollar startup, and you’re only working with a team of two. The New York Times is reporting that 
it’s happening now, and AI is making it possible.
Startups like Gamma, founded in 2020, demonstrate how lean teams can deliver outsized results. The AI-powered presentation and website maker has achieved such financial success that CEO Grant Lee confirms they require no additional funding.
Lee told the New York Times that
 with just 28 employees, they've reached profitability, “tens of millions” in recurring revenue, and nearly 50 million users.
 
🤯 
So how does Gamma use AI to grow so quickly and profitably with such few people? Here’s how:
Intercom’s customer service tool
 to handle inquiries and resolve issues quickly, reducing the need for a large support team.
Midjourney’s image generator
 to create visuals fast, cutting down on time spent on creative work.
Anthropic’s Claude chatbot
 helps Gamma analyze data efficiently, providing actionable insights for decision-making.
Google’s NotebookLM
 accelerates the process of analyzing customer research, helping the team stay agile and informed.
Engineers use 
Anysphere’s Cursor
 to write code more quickly, enabling faster development with fewer resources.
And Gamma isn’t an outlier. 
Silicon Valley is buzzing about "tiny teams" - companies achieving impressive annual revenue with remarkably small workforces, leveraging AI to do what previously required hundreds of people. 
Midjourney’s team of 10 hit $200M after just 2 years
Cursor’s team of 20 hit $100M in 2 years
Magnific and Aragon.ai hit $10M with teams of less than 10
The real takeaway here is that AI isn't just a tool to help you save a few minutes anymore. It’s fundamentally changing how businesses structure themselves. 
Think you have 
the next great million-dollar idea
? You don't need massive investment or a massive workforce. With AI tools becoming commonplace, the playing field has never been more level. 
😎 
  
Generative AI is redefining how businesses grow—are you keeping up?
Smaller teams are scaling faster by using AI to streamline work, cut costs, and focus on what truly drives growth,
 even in large organizations
. It’s no longer about hiring huge teams: it’s about working smarter and knowing how to apply AI for real impact.
A lot of leaders I talk to wonder where to start with Generative AI projects. That’s exactly what I cover in my 
Generative AI for Business Executives
 course—practical strategies to make AI work for your business.
The next cohort starts in
 5 days
: If you’re thinking about taking that first step, now’s a good time.
Secure Your Spot Today 
  
Could Cyborg Cockroaches Have Helped During the LA Fires?
In 2011, a massive earthquake and tsunami hit Japan, with rescue teams unable to locate as many as 18,000 people beneath the collapsed buildings.
Motivated by the struggle to reach survivors in dangerous, tight spaces, Hirotaka Sato set out to create tech that could access those areas. 
To do this, 
Sato and his team of researchers at Osaka University and Diponegoro University in Indonesia are turning to cockroaches
, nature’s resilient little survivors. The team has developed tiny electronic devices that can be attached to cockroaches, combining their natural survival skills with tech to help them navigate complex environments. 
Here’s how it works
: 
Sensors detect motion and obstacles, providing navigation commands when needed. 
Otherwise, the circuit stays out of the way, letting the insects navigate and recover from falls on their own.
The team tested the cyborgs on obstacle courses with sand, stones, and wood. Even in complex, unfamiliar environments, the cockroaches successfully overcame obstacles and reached their target.
The entire system is very energy-efficient, meaning the cockroaches can work longer than traditional robots in harsh environments. The “cyborg cockroach” offers several helpful applications:
Inspect areas that are too dangerous for humans to access, such as collapsed buildings or unstable structures.
Navigate pipes, tunnels, and other confined spaces where robots cannot fit.
Potential for deep-sea and space exploration, where oxygen is scarce or conditions are extreme.
Use in delicate areas that require minimal human intervention, such as historical sites or archaeological digs.
I can't help but think how helpful such cyborg cockroaches could've been in the recent 
LA
 
wildfires,
 which destroyed over 12,000 structures and forced 300,000 residents to evacuate. 
😢
 Rescue teams faced unstable buildings and hidden dangers that made their work extremely hazardous.
These cyborg cockroaches could have crawled through debris, reaching trapped survivors and detecting hazards like gas leaks—without putting human lives at risk.
It’s interesting how the tech blends millions of years of evolution with today’s tech. Cockroaches are notoriously resilient, so using them to navigate difficult environments is a no-brainer. My question is, how do they ensure the circuit itself stays safe?
  
Would You Get This Robot Do Your Chores?
Protoclone V1 is 
a humanoid robot with 1,000 artificial muscles
—and an interesting trick: it sweats to stay cool.
Most robots move with stiff, jerky motions because they rely on rigid motors. Protoclone V1 is different: it uses soft, pressurized “muscles” that expand and contract like real human muscles, letting it move more smoothly and naturally while also conserving energy. A built-in water-based cooling system prevents overheating, mimicking how humans regulate temperature.
Clone Robotics says future versions could wash dishes, vacuum, fold laundry, and even make sandwiches. 
While I love the idea of a robot that vacuums and makes me sandwiches… a creepy, sweating robot lurking in my kitchen? 
😨
 I’d never be able to sleep. What do you think?
Would you let this sweaty robot do your chores?
Yes, if it folds laundry, I’ll ignore the fact that it’s a possessed mannequin. 😁 
Maybe… but only if it doesn’t start smelling like a gym bro. 🤔 
A sweaty roommate? Feels like freshman year all over again. 🙊 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
Google’s AI 
just solved a decade-long scientific mystery in 2 days
. 
Professor José R. Penadés and his team at Imperial College London spent years figuring out how superbugs become resistant to antibiotics. When they gave Google’s AI “co-scientist” the same challenge, it reached the same conclusion in just 48 hours. 
It didn’t end there. The AI even suggested 4 more possible explanations, including one the team had never even considered and is now actively exploring. 
For Penadés, this is a turning point. Research has always been limited by how long it takes to form and test the right hypothesis. Today, AI is collapsing that timeline. Instead of spending years narrowing down possibilities, scientists can start from stronger hypotheses right away. 
  
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️

LinkedIn
 and 
Instagram

here
.

subject: Re: Questions about new ML build
body:
Hi Keri,
How is your week going? Things are good here in Cleveland. The weather is finally a bit warmer!
I wanted to touch base again on my previous question about building a new Microlearning....but this time more around e-Learnings.
Some questions for you:
What is your comfort level building an EL or ML from scratch? 
When I say "from scratch," I mean that we don't have any content for it yet, so you'd have to work closely with an LCW SME to create.
How would you feel about taking existing LCW facilitated content & making it into an EL?
 For example, using our "Women in Leadership Spotlight" PPT deck as a guide to build an EL.
I'd love to learn if this is something you're interested in, how long you think it might take to do this, and how you would charge - we could do hourly, or we could perhaps come up with a set price per project. For example, we pay you $X amount to turn a facilitated training into an EL.
We probably should get on a call to discuss, but I wanted to send this to you first so you could think on it. 🙂 If you're interested in doing either above, LMK, and I'll schedule a time to chat.
Thank you!
Nicole

subject: [Expensify] Travel and expense, at the speed of chat
body:
tl;dr - Introducing Expensify Travel: fully managed corporate travel via web, app, or chat – now available to every Expensify member
 
Travel and expense should go hand in hand… and now they can! We've long been asked by customers big and small for the ability to: 
Book flights, hotels, rail, and car rentals from inside the app.
Limit what inventory employees see to only what is in the authorized travel policy.
Pay for these bookings using a central virtual card.
Capture the travel receipts into an automatic expense report.
Cut travel costs
In 
New Expensify
, press the green + button 
> Book travel
 (or in 
Expensify Classic
, click the 
Travel
 button along the left side of the screen). It does all the things you expect (in-policy booking results, travel-based spend analysis, out-of-policy notices, approvals before booking, duty-of-care reporting), plus a few tricks you don't – courtesy of the realtime chat framework of the New Expensify superapp: 
Realtime duty of care
, which lets you know where all your employees are at all times. We even connect the traveler and travel manager in a dedicated chat room to discuss all bookings and changes the instant they happen, rather than whenever you get around to checking your inbox.
Realtime expense management,
 where every booking receipt and change fee is recorded as an expense that's submitted up through Expensify's realtime approval and next-day reimbursement engine: book today, get paid tomorrow!
Realtime collaboration
, where shared trip chat rooms are automatically created in New Expensify so that everyone is on the same page. From employees to managers, everything you need to know about your trip, all in one place. 
The instant, chat-first design of New Expensify is why we like to say that Expensify does:
Travel and expense at the speed of chat.
To check it out, open your Expensify app and click 
Travel
, or take a peek below!
It's one of the most exciting times to be at Expensify that I can ever remember. We have a 
lot
 going on, and it's energizing to be sharing it with you after so long in development. Keep an eye out for a ton more on the way!
-david
Founder and CEO of Expensify
Questions? Ask me in the 
#new-expensify-feedback
 room! 
PS: Check out OpenAI's work on building an 
artificial engineer
 to solve Expensify App open source projects!
Sent by: Expensify, Inc. - 548 Market St #61434 - San Francisco, CA 94103
To unsubscribe, please click 
here

body:
PLUS, would you let AI fix your bad pickup lines?  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
February 25, 2025   |   
Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hey everyone, hope your week is going well!
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
Is Saudi Arabia the Next Global AI Hub? 
Elon Musk’s Grok 3 Chatbot is Really Good
Would You Let AI Fix Your Bad Pickup Lines?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
Is Saudi Arabia the Next Global AI Hub? 
In a strategic move to enhance its AI capabilities, 
The Kingdom of Saudi Arabia has committed $1.5 billion to Groq
, a Silicon Valley-based AI chip manufacturer. 
What is Groq? 
Founded by ex-Google engineers, Groq develops AI chips designed for one thing: speed. 
Unlike Nvidia chips that are more general purpose, Groq 
chips are built to accelerate AI inference
, making AI-powered applications—like chatbots, recommendation engines, and self-driving cars—run faster and more efficiently. 
[ps. 
AI inference is when a trained AI system makes predictions or takes actions based on new data, just like using past knowledge to solve new problems. It's the moment an AI actually does its job, whether that's recognizing your face, translating text, or generating an image from your description.]
The Kingdom’s Strategic Play: 
Speed matters to Saudi Arabia because fast, efficient AI inference capabilities directly support Vision 2030's tech hubs, smart cities, and AI infrastructure that require real-time processing across urban management and financial services.
The Kingdom also aims to use Groq’s high-speed inference capabilities to develop and improve its Arabic-language AI, including the ALLaM model, to smarter Arabic-speaking assistants, improved search engines, and enhanced medical diagnostics for the region.
The investment in Groq supports this goal by building state-of-the-art data centers and attracting top tech talent, enhancing AI inference capabilities for regional and global customers.
The strategic partnership with Groq is one of many steps the Kingdom is taking as it 
transitions from oil dependency to a diversified, technology-driven economy
 while positioning itself as an emerging global AI hub
. 
😎 
  
Elon Musk’s Grok 3 Chatbot is Really Good
When Elon Musk launched xAI in 2023, skeptics questioned his ability to compete in the AI space. Yet within two years, he's released five versions of his Generative AI chatbot Grok, with 
Grok 3 gaining significant attention
.
Upon release, Grok saw mobile downloads increase tenfold, US daily users grow 260%, and web visits jump to 4.5 million globally. 
(ps. for context, Grok still trails far behind OpenAI's 400 million weekly active users). 
What Makes Grok Different?
Massive Computing Power
: Grok 3 was trained with 10x the computing resources of earlier versions on a supercomputer with 200,000 Nvidia GPUs.
Alternative AI Approach
: Unlike OpenAI, xAI focuses on AI gaming and X integration, positioning Grok for real-time social engagement.
Live Information Updates
: Grok pulls current data including real-time X updates, giving users more timely information than models with fixed training data.
The Good, The Bad and The Ugly: 
The Good: 
Many users across social media report Grok 3 delivers impressive speed and capabilities compared to previous versions. 
The Bad:
 The platform has faced controversy over performance measurement disputes with OpenAI.
The Ugly: 
There are reports that Grok was preprogrammed to avoid sources claiming Musk spread misinformation. Eeek.
I’ve been using it and I think it’s fast and analytical (I always use multiple AI chatbots including Perplexity, Claude, ChatGPT, Gemini and DeepSeek for my work and now have added Grok to the list as well).
It's free for all X users. Grok 3's paid version is called SuperGrok, which is priced at $30 per month. Try it out!
  
Would You Let AI Fix Your Bad Pickup Lines?
You’ve probably been there—a dating app message that makes you cringe. Maybe it’s way too forward, maybe it’s just really weird. But what if AI could step in before things go off the rails?
Tinder and Hinge are testing a new AI feature that detects when a message might be too aggressive or inappropriate
 and prompts the sender to rethink before hitting send. 1 in 5 users actually change their message after seeing the warning.
It’s a good move for safer, more respectful conversations. But it should stay a nudge, not a script. 
If AI starts suggesting messages, it could let bad actors sound safe without actually being safe.
With Gen Z experiencing dating app fatigue, platforms are looking for ways to make online dating feel less exhausting. AI might be able to help, but can a pop-up really teach people to be better human beings? What do you think?
Would you use a dating app that asks you to rethink your messages?
Yes! A small reminder can make conversations more thoughtful and kind. ❤ 
Maybe, but I’d rather people learn to be respectful on their own. 🤔 
No way! It could help the wrong people seem trustworthy. 😡 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
DBS Group, Southeast Asia’s largest bank, 
is phasing out 4,000 temporary and contract jobs over the next three years
 as AI takes on more tasks. With nearly 9,000 contract staff currently, the cuts will happen gradually through natural attrition—meaning no sudden layoffs, and permanent employees remain unaffected. 
This isn’t just a DBS story. 
A Bloomberg Intelligence report estimates that AI could replace up to 200,000 banking jobs worldwide in the next five years as automation 
takes over routine tasks in customer service, compliance, and back-office operations. 
DBS’s decision highlights how automation is shifting jobs in the banking sector. 
If you’re a worker, this is only a reminder that the key is adjusting to a workplace where AI plays a bigger role. As routine tasks get automated, the focus will shift to skills like problem-solving, decision-making, and working with AI tools. 
  
Is your business ready to thrive in the AI-driven future?
"Where do I start with AI?"
This is one of the most common questions I get from executives and business leaders. The real challenge isn’t just understanding AI, it’s knowing how to apply it for real impact. 
That’s exactly what I focus on in my 
Generative AI for Business Executives
 course. 
Over the years, I’ve helped leaders integrate AI to boost productivity, drive profitability, and create real business value. This course is designed to give you the practical insights and frameworks to do the same. 
If you’re ready to take that first step, 
secure your spot
 today 😎 
ps. We’re just 
9 days 
away from the next cohort starting on March 4th. 
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️ 
ps. Let's be friends on 
LinkedIn
 and 
Instagram
, if you like this newsletter, share it with your friends and family 
here
. 
  
FROM OUR PARTNERS
Your daily AI dose 
Mindstream
 is the HubSpot Media Network’s hottest new property. Stay on top of AI, learn how to apply it… and actually enjoy reading. Imagine that. 
Our small team of actual humans spends their whole day creating a newsletter that’s loved by over 150,000 readers. Why not give us a try?

subject: Unlock the Secrets of Global Trust – Learn with Expert Maria Todosiychuk!
body:
Register Now for Our March 12th Global Trust Webinar! ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Global Trust
Unlocking the Power of Cross-Cultural Connections
Registration now for this March 12th Webinar!
 
 
 
 
March 12, 2025 @ 11:30AM ET
 
 
 
 
 
Data from international surveys sheds light on the following questions: What is trust and why does it matter? How profitable is trust? How much real trust is there in the world? How is trust created across cultures? Using a case study, this session is designed to provide practical insights and actionable takeaways that participants can apply in their personal and professional contexts. This Global Trust session will deliver ideas about one of the most fundamental cross-cultural challenges and about building real bridges. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
NON-MEMBER REGISTRATION 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
PRESENTER:
 
Based in Russia, 
Maria Todosiychuk
 is an old friend and colleague of SIETAR USA. She is known for her educational games such as Diversity Space Meeting, Culture Shock, The Global Team, and Intercultural Minefield which are used by many interculturalists across Europe and the USA for intercultural training. Honed over 15 years of working with major Russian and international corporations, Maria has her own style and views on how to teach tricky and complicated intercultural topics. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Unsubscribe
 | Sent by SIETAR USA 
4880 Lower Roswell Rd, Suite 165 • Marietta , GA • 30068

subject: Does Prenuvo Know You’re Sick Before You Do?
body:
AI news, leaders, business insights and more  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 7 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hey everyone, hope your week is going well! 
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
Does Prenuvo Know You’re Sick Before You Do?
Workday Is Making an HR Team for Your AI Agents
Would You Feed Your Pet Lab-Grown Treats?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
Does Prenuvo Know You’re Sick Before You Do?
Image: @kimkardashian (Instagram)
Most people only address health issues once symptoms appear.
The healthcare company Prenuvo wants to change this by 
identifying disease before problems emerge
. 
Having secured 
$120M in new funding
 and with celebrity backing from Kim Kardashian and Paris Hilton, the company is expanding globally after reaching $100M in revenue and serving 110,000 U.S. clients last year.
What Prenuvo Does
Prenuvo's proprietary MRI technology scans 26 body regions in under an hour, 
detecting over 500 conditions including cancer and aneurysms
 - much faster than traditional 3-4 hour MRIs. 
The current scan costs $2,500 (not covered by insurance), with a new $3,999 package coming that adds blood tests, enhanced brain scanning, and AI body composition analysis.
The Controversy
The company's success stories are compelling – early-stage cancers caught before spreading, dangerous aneurysms discovered before rupturing. But the company isn’t without controversy.
Medical experts caution that these high-resolution scans often detect minor, harmless abnormalities like small cysts or benign nodules. 
This can lead to unnecessary follow-up tests, specialist visits, and anxiety over conditions that may resolve naturally.
I strongly believe in proactive healthcare, but I've received conflicting medical advice - one doctor recommended such screenings while another cautioned against it.
One thing is clear: 
AI-powered diagnostics are the future of preventative healthcare.
  
Workday Is Making an HR Team for Your AI Agents
Imagine having AI Jensen Huang as an employee at your business. Image: NVIDIA
Workday, a major Human Resources and finance software provider, 
is introducing a new system to help businesses manage their AI agents in one place
.
What are AI agents?
AI agents are computer programs that work independently of humans to complete tasks - like a virtual assistant scheduling your meetings, chatbots answering customer inquiries or agents handling complex tasks like making
 sophisticated decisions about alternate routes or suppliers.
Investors expect that AI agents offered by startups like Salesforce and Glean will become commonplace and become our "digital colleagues".
A System to Manage AI agents
Currently, there's no structured way to oversee AI agents across an organization.
 This is why NVIDIA CEO Jensen Huang said that he envisions a future where IT teams function as the "HR department" for AI agents, overseeing their onboarding, training, and management.
Workday’s Agent System of Record is one such 
HR equivalent for AI agents
. It will give companies a way to see what each AI agent is doing, control who has access to them and track costs and overall impact.
Why this matters: 
With AI agents managing sensitive company data like payroll, intellectual property and financial audits, they will have to be controlled and governed by a proper system. 
The emergence of Workday’s system underscores the growing recognition that AI agents will become integral components of the workforce and organizations will need a way to accommodate both human and AI labor.
  
Would You Feed Your Pet Lab-Grown Treats?
Image: Meatly
Even our furry friends are getting a taste of the future now. 
London-based startup Meatly has launched 
the world’s first lab-grown meat treat for pets
, now available in the UK.
Made from cultured animal cells, lab-grown meat is designed to use less land, water, and resources than traditional meat production—without harming animals. The pet treat, called “Chick Bites,” contains 4% cultivated chicken and is currently in limited release.
With pet food accounting for 20% of global meat consumption, some see it as a step towards a more sustainable future. What do you think?
Would you feed your dog lab-grown food?
Sustainable, ethical, and my pet won’t know the difference? I’m in. 🤩 
Maybe, but where’s my lab-grown pizza? 😤 
No way, my pet eats nothing except real meat.🚫 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
Perplexity 
has introduced its freemium Deep Research tool
, offering a more accessible option for those looking to conduct in-depth research. Unlike OpenAI’s $200/month subscription, Perplexity offers a free version with limited daily queries, making it a more affordable choice for casual users. Paying subscribers get unlimited access, providing flexibility for those who need it. 
What sets this tool apart is its speed—tasks are completed in under three minutes, compared to the 5 to 30 minutes it can take other tools. This means users can get detailed, citation-backed answers quickly, which could be useful for time-sensitive tasks. 
Benchmark scores put Perplexity ahead of Gemini and Grok but just behind OpenAI. 
ps. I’ve been using Deep Research by ChatGPT, Perplexity and DeepSeek and all three are really good. 
  
🚀 Ready to lead your company’s AI transformation? 
The countdown is on—just 2 weeks to go until the 4th cohort of my Generative AI for Business Executives course starts on March 4th. 
Don’t miss this chance to future-proof your organization. 
Secure your spot
 today 😎 
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️

subject: RE: Staff Announcement - Larry Baker
body:
Hi Larry! 
I’m sad you’re leaving your full-time job. But I believe your talent will land you better opportunities. 
Being a contractor isn't bad at all, at least for me. My time is more flexible, and I can do more things I enjoy and work for other people. You might like it too. 
 
Most importantly, I hope you are happy, and I wish you good luck in your search for new opportunities.
 
Best,
~Keri 
 
From:
 Larry Baker <l.baker@lcwmail.com> 
Sent:
 Friday, February 14, 2025 11:00 AM
To:
 Andrea Wicks Bowles <a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Office <office@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 RE: Staff Announcement - Larry Baker
 
Who’s cutting onions in here!!! 
☹
 
 
If I tell you that I have enjoyed every moment of my time here, it will still fall short of my feelings!! I have had the pleasure of working with folks that I respect and care for during my time here. 
 
I won’t say goodbye, I’ll just say see you soon!!
 
Best,
 
LBJ
 
From:
 Andrea Wicks Bowles <
a.wicksbowles@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, February 14, 2025 10:32 AM
To:
 Larry Baker <
l.baker@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Staff Announcement - Larry Baker
 
Hey Larry,
What can I say…  I have been so lucky to be a co-facilitator or 
just
 “
the consultant in the session
” -- and watched you present difficult and complex information with such expertise and humility.  Participants felt you were talking to them in an honest non-judgmental manner.  You created just the right setting for adult learning.
 
Professionally and personally, I will miss you greatly.  Please stay in touch 
awicksbowles@gmail.com
 
 
Cheers~
 
Andrea Wicks Bowles
(She/Her/Hers)
Senior Consultant
LCW

From:

c.adams@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Friday, February 14, 2025 11:06 AM
To:
 Office <
office@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Staff Announcement - Larry Baker
 
Dear Team,
 
At the end of the day today, we bid farewell to Larry Baker as a full time employee. Larry has been a cornerstone of our facilitations and programs. His expertise, professionalism, and ability to create engaging and impactful sessions have been invaluable to our organization.
 
Larry has played a pivotal role in delivering meaningful experiences for our clients, helping them navigate complex topics and fostering deeper understanding through his thoughtful facilitation. His ability to connect with people, guide discussions, and inspire growth has left a lasting impression on everyone he’s worked with. We are incredibly grateful for the energy and dedication he has brought to his role. 
 
Please join me in thanking Larry for his outstanding work and we look forward to working with him as a contractor.
 
With gratitude,
 
Chuck/Nicole
 
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Chief Executive Officer

🙁

The good news is that Catalina has helped us find her replacement - Jorgelina's (Lina). Lina is just as amazing as Catalina, and I know you will enjoy working with her. Lina has started, is based in Argentina, & will be training with Catalina to get up to speed. Lina will also be joining our all-staff meeting on Tuesday. Please reach out to her for a warm welcome! 
 
Welcome Lina!
 
 
Nicole Barile

subject: The Google Effect: Why We Remember Less but Feel Smarter
body:
AI news, leaders, business insights and more  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ 
February 15, 2025   |   
Read Online
 
Dr. Ayesha Khanna 
Reading Time: 8 minutes 
 
In partnership with
Hey everyone, wishing you a fab weekend! 😎
Here’s Today’s Tech News:
The Google Effect: Why We Remember Less but Feel Smarter
Meet Nancy Xu, Founder & CEO of Moonhub AI
Would You Watch Robots Compete in Sports?
Articles I’ve Been Reading
  
NEWS YOU CAN’T MISS
The Google Effect: Why We Remember Less but Feel Smarter
Is over-reliance on tech turning us all into Dory, the forgetful fish from Finding Dory? Video: Pixar
Ever walked into a room and immediately forgotten why you’re there? Or Googled something only to forget it seconds later? You’re not alone.
Scientists have found evidence that 
tech is changing the way we remember things
—how we store and retrieve memories. Instead of holding onto information, we’ve learned to rely on digital tools to do the remembering for us.
Here’s what they found:
We remember where to find info, not the info itself
: This is called the ‘Google Effect’—our brains have learned that we don’t need to store facts because Google will always be there to look them up.
GPS is messing with our sense of direction
: Studies show that people who rely on GPS struggle to recall routes later, just like those who’ve never driven them at all.
AI could take this even further
: A study found that people who used Google to answer trivia questions thought they had better memory than those who answered without it—just because they felt smarter.
AI-generated info can rewrite our memory
: AI doesn’t just retrieve facts; it creates them. Chatbots sometimes generate false details, and over time, we might start believing things that never actually happened.
Should you be worried? Well, our brains have always adapted to new ways of storing and finding information—from telling stories around a fire to writing things down in books to looking everything up online. AI is just the latest step in that evolution.
But there’s a key difference: 
past technologies helped us store and retrieve knowledge, while AI actively reshapes it. 
We’re not just outsourcing memory; we’re relying on AI to filter, summarize, and even generate information for us. If we stop engaging with that process, the risk isn’t just forgetting things—it’s losing the habit of thinking critically about what we’re being told.
So go ahead and use AI as a tool, but let’s all make sure we stay actively engaged with what you learn. Thinking critically is an invaluable skill in an age of AI. ♥️
  
Are you leveraging Generative AI to drive business growth?
Join my course ‘Generative AI for Business Executives’, and gain the tools, strategies, and confidence to future-proof your organization. 
Exclusive for my newsletter readers: A 
special discount
 to enroll. 😊 
Here’s what a recent participant had to say: 
“This is an awesome nugget-sized learning that can provide fundamental yet essential explanations of how Generative AI can impact businesses. Excellent!”
— Moira (Global Strategic Marketing Manager - LSEG) 
  
WOMAN IN TECH
Meet Nancy Xu, Founder & CEO of Moonhub AI
Celebrating this week's Woman in Tech 
🥳
: Meet 
Nancy Xu, founder and CEO of Moonhub
, an AI-powered recruiting platform used by billion-dollar companies to hire top talent.
Born in China and raised in the US, Xu became 
the first person to complete a dual PhD in AI and MBA at Stanford
. She trained for the US Math and Physics teams as a student and later co-founded The Gradient, a widely read AI publication focused on research and industry developments.
She began her career at Meta’s AI research division before leading healthcare AI and automation at AKASA.
In 2022, she founded Moonhub, aiming to improve hiring with AI. Unlike traditional recruiting tools that rely on keyword searches, Moonhub’s AI scans billions of data points from platforms like LinkedIn, GitHub, and Google Scholar to identify qualified candidates. 
The startup has seen remarkable success:
Secured over $14M in funding from investors like Khosla Ventures, GV, and Marc Benioff.
Surpassed $1M in revenue in its first year.
Used by 100+ companies, including 
AI unicorns like Inflection and Anthropic
.
Beyond Moonhub, Xu is an active investor through Xu Ventures, backing early-stage AI startups shaping the future of work. Her contributions to AI and the recruiting industry have earned her a spot on TIME’s 100 Most Influential People in AI (2023).
My fave quote from Xu: 
“One of the biggest gifts that I've been given is access to opportunity. I believe that one of the best things and the greatest gifts you can give to anyone on this planet is access to opportunity.”
  
Would You Watch Robots Compete in Sports?
Video: Science X (YouTube)
Move over, Cristiano. We have a new man of the match. 
😎 
Scientists at Carnegie Mellon University and NVIDIA have developed 
an AI system that teaches robots to pull off signature moves from world-class athletes
.
In a recent demonstration, a robot successfully performed Cristiano Ronaldo’s mid-air spin and LeBron James’ game-winning shot, which is a big deal when it comes to teaching robots full-body movement.
The system, called ASAP (Aligning Simulation and Real Physics), allows robots to study real sports footage, breaking down human motion and translating it into robotic actions with impressive accuracy.
While it’s a big advancement in robotics, many feel that their movements are still robotic and not very agile. The question remains, could professional robot sports become a thing, or would the lack of human finesse take the thrill out of the game? What do you think?
Would you watch AI robot sports?
Yes! Finally, a team that won’t blame the refs for losing. 😎 
Maybe, but only if they can trash talk like the real pros. 🤩 
And miss out on real pros faking an injury for drama? Hard pass. 😒 
  
LATELY
Articles I’ve Been Reading:
Spain is set to 
cut its workweek from 40 to 37.5 hours starting next year
, aiming to improve work-life balance. The proposal, championed by Labor Minister Yolanda Díaz, faces opposition from business leaders, who walked out of negotiations, citing concerns over profitability and rigid corporate planning. 
The measure, benefiting 13 million workers, follows last week’s minimum wage hike and is part of the government’s broader interventionist policies. While unions support it, critics draw parallels to France’s controversial 35-hour workweek. With Spain’s economy growing at 3.2% in 2024—outpacing France, Italy, and Germany—the move also seeks to boost voter support for Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez’s government. 
The bill’s fate in Congress remains uncertain, hinging on pro-business Catalan and Basque nationalist parties. If passed, Spain would rank among the European countries with the shortest official workweeks. 😲 
  
Until next time! 
Ayesha ❤️

From:

k.luo@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Thursday, February 13, 2025 1:02 PM
To:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Questions about new ML build
 
 
Hi Nicole!
 
Here are the answers to your question: 
It depends on how long and how complexity the microlearning will be. It typically takes about 5 to 8 days to build.
If it’s a microlearning, I will use Rise. (The storyline is for larger courses.) 
Same as #1. 
Yes, both Rise and Storyline support translation into other languages (by exporting the course content as an XLIFF file, which can then be translated by translators and imported back into Rise to create a multilingual version of the course.)  
Yes, I can easily do that.
 
I hope that helps. Feel free to call me if you want to know more details.
 
Best,
~Keri
 
From:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
> 
Sent:
 Thursday, February 13, 2025 11:40 AM
To:
 Keri Luo <
k.luo@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Questions about new ML build
 
Hello Keri,
 
I hope you're having a great week!
 
We may have a client who wants a new microlearning build, and I have several questions:
How long does it take you, on average, to turn an existing LCW training (from PPT) into an elearning or microloearning?
I think you're doing something for Andrea for Rockwell...
Do you typically use Rise or Storyline for LCW?
How long would it take you, on average, to create a new microlearning from scratch (assuming the course is around 30 minutes or less)?
This is assuming someone from LCW would work with you on the content, as a subject matter expert
Does Rise and/or Storyline allow for translation into other languages?
If Yes, is this something you can do? (We would have professional translators review for accuracy / QA)
If No, do you know of a workaround (ex: translating outside of Rise/Storyline & then importing the translation)
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Happy to also hop on a call if easier to talk through.
Thanks so much!
Nicole

Thanks again!
Nicole

Subject:

Hi Nicole!
 
Here are the answers to your question: 
It depends on how long and how complexity the microlearning will be. It typically takes about 5 to 8 days to build.
If it’s a microlearning, I will use Rise. (The storyline is for larger courses.) 
Same as #1. 
Yes, both Rise and Storyline support translation into other languages (by exporting the course content as an XLIFF file, which can then be translated by translators and imported back into Rise to create a multilingual version of the course.)  
Yes, I can easily do that.
 
I hope that helps. Feel free to call me if you want to know more details.
 
Best,
~Keri

Hello Keri,
 
I hope you're having a great week!
 
We may have a client who wants a new microlearning build, and I have several questions:
How long does it take you, on average, to turn an existing LCW training (from PPT) into an elearning or microloearning?
I think you're doing something for Andrea for Rockwell...
Do you typically use Rise or Storyline for LCW?
How long would it take you, on average, to create a new microlearning from scratch (assuming the course is around 30 minutes or less)?
This is assuming someone from LCW would work with you on the content, as a subject matter expert
Does Rise and/or Storyline allow for translation into other languages?
If Yes, is this something you can do? (We would have professional translators review for accuracy / QA)
If No, do you know of a workaround (ex: translating outside of Rise/Storyline & then importing the translation)
Please let me know if you have any questions.
Happy to also hop on a call if easier to talk through.
Thanks so much!
Nicole
